caseTitle: NII NARH DOWUONA II v ADDOKWEI TETTEH OLEWOLON & 3 ORS
summary: This is a civil appeal before the Supreme Court of Ghana concerning a land dispute between the Boi Stool, represented by Nii Narh Dowuona II, and the defendants, Addokwei Tetteh Olewolon and others, who claim title through the Numo Nmashie family of Teshie. The plaintiff sought a declaration of title to 87.68 acres of land at Boi near Abokobi, perpetual injunction against trespass, and general damages. The trial High Court and Court of Appeal dismissed the claim, finding the plaintiff failed to prove title. The Supreme Court upheld the lower courts' decisions, emphasizing fatal contradictions between the plaintiff’s testimony and that of his witnesses regarding the mode of ancestral acquisition of the land—vacant land versus conquest. The Court held that such internal inconsistencies undermined the plaintiff’s case, distinguishing this from rival traditional histories. The defendants relied on a prior Court of Appeal judgment (Civil Case No. 49/80) concerning Adjancote Hill, asserting estoppel. The Supreme Court found no error in the lower courts’ evaluation and affirmed that the plaintiff did not discharge the burden of proof on a balance of probabilities.
legalKeywords: Court of Appeal Civil Case No. 49/80
verdict: Appeal dismissed. Decision of the Court of Appeal and trial High Court affirmed.
citations: Adjei bi Kojo v Bonsie (1957) 3 WALR 257
rationaleHighlights: Appellant failed to prove title due to contradictions between his testimony and that of his witnesses
Principle in Adjei Kojo v Bonsie does not apply where contradictions are within a party's own evidence
Trial court's finding supported by evidence; appellate courts affirmed preference for defendants' case
Estoppel per rem judicatam raised based on prior Court of Appeal judgment in Civil Case No. 49/80
Appellate duty to review entire record affirmed, but not violated in this case
